question.text: The elongated or tube-like cells, with thick, lignified walls and tapering ends are

solution.text:
Xylem is made up of four different kinds of elements in which tracheids are oldest, elongated with thick-walled structures. Tracheids are the main xylem elements in a gymnosperm.

4 types of xylem elements are -

1. Tracheids: Elongated cells with tapering ends. Dead cells (no protoplasm) with lignified cell walls.

2. Vessels (Tracheae): Vessel is tubular structure made up of cells (vessel members) joined together end to end. Dead cells (no protoplasm) with lignified cell walls and a large central cavity. Members are interconnected by their perforated end walls. These are characteristic features of angiosperms (gymnosperms lack vessels).

3. Xylem fibers: Elongated cells with tapering ends and obliterated lumen. Dead cells (no protoplasm) with lignified cell walls. These may be septate or aseptate.

4. Xylem parenchyma: Living cells with a thin cell wall made up of cellulose. These store food (starch, oil), tannin, etc. Ray parenchymatous cells also perform radial conduction of water.
